page.lettertext:
fol.168r
Belgia 1591 22 June To my L. Trea
s
Belgia 1591 June
May yt please yo
r
good L. the 13 of this moneth I
advertised yo
r
L. of my being at
Dockum
w
th
e
Councell
of State
, from whence wee tooke o
r
Journey toward
e army.
But before wee came theth
r
wee had woord from the
Count
that
e Ennemy at
Groeningen
had opened certain sluces, wherby
of 6
tes about
e towne, there were 5 over flowed, &
e
army on
e soddain forced to disloge. The possibility to let
in
e water was neither knowen to
Count William
, nor to
e
Deputies of
Friseland,
on whom
e army depended for good
direction in
e siege. For they were al
swaded
t
e water
of those sluces could not hinder o
r
approches; nor
e pl
a
ting
of
e Artillery. But since yt fell out oth
r
wise yt was thought
convenient that o
r
forces should p
nt
ly marche toward
Delfzile
w
ch
ys a strong fort up
o
e Ems distant from Groningnen Northe
east, 3 long Dutche miles. The taking of this fort, because
yt
s
veth as a haven to Groningen, was generally thought of
singular importance. There was order also taken
t
e artillery
w
ch
was not yet disbarked but onely kept in a redynes in
e ships
before Groningen, should be brought to Delfzele by water.
Up
o
this resolution
e Councel of State finding no security for
them selves to goe to Delfzile by land, when
e troupes were
de
ted, went thither by shipp. P
nt
ly upon o
r
coming the approches
were made, & as yesternight
e artillery made ready to be planted
wherupon
e Enemey w
th
in, albeyt for
e space of 3 daies hee
had shott uppon us very hotly, uppon
e first summoning
condescended to a parle & surrendred p
nt
ly upon like composition
as those of
Deventer
&
Zutphen.
Theyr want w
th
in was both
of men & powder, & no kinde of hope to be relieved by
e
Spaniard. Groningen excepted, there are onely now remayning
in
e territory of Groningen
e fort
of
Opslack
&
emmentile
w
ch
are fort
of some strength, lyeng southwest from Groningen
w
th
in 2 or 4 leagues, but unable to w
th
stand any forceable
battery. For w
ch
it is resolved, that
ey shall be summond
owt of hand. And as for those of Groningen, yt ys first
intreated, for that now yt ys thought, they will hearken to reason
that they shalbee moved by fayre offers, to unite them selves to
fol.168v
Belgia: 1591: June
the other Provinces: w
ch
if they chaunce to reject, as moste
men think they will, reposing no confidence in any promise
of
e States, then they do determine as I am told underhand
(for as yet of them selves they do not signify so much unto
mee) to use her
Ma
t
Countenance by my meanes, to
e
effect of that commission, w
ch
was graunted unto mee
about 12 moneth
agoe/ For mine owne
te, because yt
is a matter that doth towch themselves, & becaus I know
yt is theyr humo
r
not to use her Ma
ty
but as a refuge in
extremity, I doe not deale by
swasyon either on way
or other. For yf they cannot speed of
em selves, they
will come very willingly to crave her Hig
nes
assistance, &
oth
r
wise for mee to move th
e
therunto, consydering how slightly
they regarded yt before, I knowe not how yt would stand w
th
e [humo
r
] of her Ma
tye
. Howbeyt I do see aswell by this
as by many oth
r
theyr
ceeding
, that whoseov
r
will not beare
w
th
theyr diffidence & Jalousie & oth
r
natural im
fections, but
exact more precisely an honorable cariage in theyr dealing
then
e advauncement of an action, shall but hinder that in
the end, w
ch
might be oth
r
wise effected, & do her Ma
ty
in
this contrey very litel good service. We have c
r
tain
information both by l
re
s intercepted & other very good intelligence
that
e
D. of Parma
is loged in a cloyster called
Marienboome
adjoyning to
e fort of
Rees
very much distressed, for lack
of vittailes & carriage, so as now we are
swaded, that
his journey ys wholy stayed, for troubling these quarters
Besides his nombers to
e uttermost, are not thowght to exceed
6000 foote & 150 horse, w
ch
are also in dissention, & in
very great misery for very many great want
, In effect for
my self I did never yet
ceave, that either the Ennemy
in these contreys was ever so
plexed, or so likely in all places
to be dishonored in his actions, as he ys at this p
nt
.
& thus &c. At
e campe before Delfzile, where
we
make o
r
entry this morning, June 22 1591.
